etymology.description: 臣(臣) (chén, "eye") + 戈(戈) (gē, "spear/weapon") = prisoner of war with blinded eyes -> later 爿(爿) (pán) added for phonetic value -> final form 臧
etymology.interpretation: Initially, 臧 depicted a slave or prisoner of war, with the components representing visually inhibited individuals (臣) controlled by force (戈). The character evolved to include a phonetic component 爿, suggesting an additional layer of meaning or a phonetic shift over time.

examples.chinese: 他将粮食臧在仓库中(他將糧食臧在倉庫中)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jiāng liángshí zāng zài cāngkù zhōng.
examples.english: He stores the grain in the warehouse.

examples.chinese: 工人先清点物资(工人先清點物資)，后将工具臧于仓房(后將工具臧於倉房)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngrén xiān qīngdiǎn wùzī, hòu jiāng gōngjù zāng yú cāngfáng.
examples.english: The workers first count the supplies, then store the tools in the warehouse.
